description: From Old French, from Latin rudimentum (“a first attempt, a beginning”), plural rudimenta (“the elements”), from rudis (“rude”); see rude.

entries.meaning: (often in the plural) A fundamental principle or skill, especially in a field of learning.
examples: We'll be learning the rudiments of thermodynamics next week.

entries.meaning: (often in the plural) A form that lacks full or complex development.
examples: I have the rudiments of an escape plan.

entries.meaning: (biology) A body part that no longer has a function
(music) In percussion, one of a selection of basic drum patterns learned as an exercise.

verbs.description: rudiment (third-person singular simple present rudiments, present participle rudimenting, simple past and past participle rudimented)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ground; to settle in first principles.
